title: 10 Questions to Ask to Understand NFTs
authorName: Jess Chao, Stanford BS / Berkeley MA (Education)

blocks.text:
| ![**CLONE X — X TAKASHI MURAKAMI by RTFKTCLONEXTM**](https://miro.medium.com/max/1200/1*RNrgM5B1yh3vp2ttJOQIAw.png) |
|:--:|
| ***CLONE X — X TAKASHI MURAKAMI by RTFKTCLONEXTM*** |

People don’t like to talk about how the very concept of ‘NFT value’ is extremely complicated — One of the most complex ideas I have ever studied! As a result, people are forced into distorted characterizations by the media, who roundly criticize these depictions. Furthermore, when people trying to learn about NFTs ask basic questions to those “in the know,” these questions are shot down as being “dumb”.

As an educator, I attest that these questions are not dumb. In fact, they’re absolutely essential — Everyone who understands NFTs more deeply was required to answer these questions for themselves at some point in their journey from JPEG to DAO. The following 10 questions are distilled from countless conversations I’ve had teaching people about NFTs. The answer to every question is a necessary step toward grasping the value of the NFT.
**1\. How is an NFT different from a JPEG?**

What’s the difference between an NFT and just “right-click saving” an image online? NFTs are pieces of the internet that can actually be owned. They exist permanently in a virtual record book that can never be changed, only added-onto. This technology allows NFTs to behave kind of like collectibles, such as baseball cards, with a verified owner.
**2\. Who cares who owns the image if anyone can just look at it?**
Just like anyone can go see a piece of art in a gallery, only the owner has the rights to sell it or commercialize it.
**3\. So can I make my own NFTs and sell them?**

Yes, anyone can make their own NFTs, but they might not be easy to sell. For example, if you made your own baseball cards, would they be as valuable to others as ones made by Major League Baseball? Or if you’re in the art world — If people don’t know you as an artist, would they be willing to pay for your work?
**4\. Why do certain NFTs sell for so much then?**

Most valuable NFTs are a part of a recognized collection. These collections have a finite number of NFTs in them and some collections have become quite famous and desirable— often for different reasons. For example, the Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) collection is now a recognized brand that celebrities and businesses buy into every week. In contrast, the CryptoPunks collection is recognized as the first NFT collection ever created. Owning a Punk is like owning a piece of technological history. As a collection becomes more valued, so does each constituent NFT.

It’s important to note that it is easy to verify online whether your NFT is part of a recognized collection or not. So while you can make an NFT for free that looks just like an NFT from a valuable collection worth thousands, anyone online can easily see that it is not an authentic piece from the original collection.
**5\. Is that all?**

NFTs are not the same thing as cryptocurrencies, speculation, profits, or scams. In fact, believe it or not, the essence of an NFT collection is actually “community”. The idea of a community of owners is built-in to the very concept of every NFT collection. The most basic example of this is the proliferation of private online chat rooms open only to individuals that can verify that they own a piece of a particular NFT collection. This aspect of value is very difficult to articulate to those who have never been a part of an NFT community. Even upon reflection, all I can say is that NFTs are uncannily effective at organizing communities of like-minded individuals both virtually and in-person — To truly comprehend what this means, I suggest jumping into one such community yourself!
**6\. So are NFTs just a way to buy friends?**

NFTs are not unlike memberships to a country club or social club, but they can be so much more. NFTs these days have moved beyond the artwork attached to them (which, I admit, is often terrible) to encompass a wide variety of different uses, or “utilities”. Some NFTs allow you to be a part-owner in a real-world asset, such as a business. Others allow you to directly support your favorite musical artists, who then share their profits with the owners of their NFTs. Simply put, NFTs are redefining ownership of both virtual and physical assets.
**7\. Why do you need NFTs to join a club or invest in a business?**

NFTs are revolutionary in the sense that they make membership or ownership easily buyable, sellable, and transferable among individuals through online marketplaces for NFTs. Ownership of particular NFTs is easily verified online by looking at your digital wallet. NFTs can even be structured into Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs), which are like mini-corporations with no central leadership that can execute decisions based on automatic voting mechanisms controlled bottom-up by NFT holders. Isn’t that wild?
**8\. Are NFTs a fad?**

Fads become popular suddenly but usually do not stay popular for very long. NFTs certainly share some characteristics of fads! For example, NFT value is rather subjective and NFTs have dramatically risen in popularity in the last year. But although the value of NFTs is completely determined by the community, this isn’t as alarming as it seems. While it may be difficult to understand at first why people value intangible assets like NFTs, let’s back up a bit and discuss value in general. Why do people value Teslas or Rolexes or that Saint Laurent leather jacket? What about abstract art? At one point in time, I guarantee you many questioned the value of items tied to such intangible worth. They don’t anymore. NFTs, I argue, are simply an evolution of what many perceive to be valuable.
**9\. So NFTs are here to stay?**

Wow, we’ve come a long way from JPEGs. Hopefully, I’ve communicated that, although people can buy, sell, and profit from their NFTs, the essence of an NFT collection is actually the community organized by virtue of shared ownership of virtual assets. Because of the power of NFTs to organize such communities, I do believe NFTs are here to stay.
**10\. What’s next?**

People are thinking up new ways to use NFTs every day. Like I mentioned before, NFTs are redefining ownership in surprising and unconventional ways. Recently, NFT owners have attempted to buy entire sports teams (or even the Constitution of the United States!). Others are using NFTs for political organization. Still others are using NFTs for the next wave of “play to earn” video games. As someone who has been in the NFT space for a while, I am still constantly being shocked by the potential of what an NFT can be. In fact, I’ve become convinced that the term “NFT” is already vastly outdated — “NFTs” are no longer a single concept but an increasingly heterogeneous group of utilities. We’ve only begun to scratch the surface of how to use this exciting technology. And the people I know working on it are nothing short of extraordinary.
The next time someone tells you they’ve got NFTs all figured out, think twice before inviting them to your Web3 dinner party ;)
